text:
Echo what Derek said about the industry. When I was working at an healthcare co w/ an avg deal size of $700k-$1M the sales team was actually our best distribution channel. We'd equip them with sales sheets, comparisons, brochures etc as part of the "content team"  We often got people onto our lists via top of funnel efforts

So I guess that's similar to an AMB play

text:
My favourite is one frowned on by some SEOs. Every blog post we publish at <https://m.io|Mio> gets republished on Medium.

Sure, we're competing against ourselves. But in some cases, Medium's SEO power doesn't just outrank us but our competitors too.

8% of our inbound traffic is attributable to Medium.

text:
There's a tedious way to do this.

1. Goto Behavior > Site Content > All Pages
2. Select the Navigation Summary tab, which is just below the Segments.
3. Use the search field below the Next Page Path on the right to find X page. On the left will be the pages visited before that page. 
4. Use the search field below the Next Page Path on the right to find the pages visited before X page. 
5. Repeat step 4 until you're satisfied.

elements.text: There's a tedious way to do this.
Goto Behavior > Site Content > All Pages
Select the Navigation Summary tab, which is just below the Segments.
Use the search field below the Next Page Path on the right to find X page. On the left will be the pages visited before that page.
Use the search field below the Next Page Path on the right to find the pages visited before X page.
Repeat step 4 until you're satisfied.

text:
Hey all! I’ve been asking around content marketing folks the following question for an upcoming article that I am working on.

Is anyone using a highlighter tool in their research/note taking phase, and how that fits in your workflow? If not, how do you save/store information, besides going for a Google search. I would love to hear your feedback in the thread below!

elements.text:

Is anyone using a highlighter tool in their research/note taking phase, and how that fits in your workflow? If not, how do you save/store information, besides going for a Google search. I would love to hear your feedback in the thread below!

text: Do you mean how to save info within articles to find it easier? I don't use any tools for that, so if anyone has suggestions, please share! For saving articles themselves, I like Swpely. <https://app.swpely.com/>

text: <@U01AU94TABA> Yes! To highlight info on different web pages or articles & later on to organize this information in folders that I can share with my colleagues. In my case, I started using <https://gosnippet.com/> about two years ago, and I am super happy with it.

text: Hey friends. How do you get respect for your timelines? How long does it take you to write a 1500 blog post with a bit of research in an industry you’re already familiar with? What do you do when you get push from other teams to rush things or get them out faster, when you know it’s not possible?

elements.text: Hey friends. How do you get respect for your timelines? How long does it take you to write a 1500 blog post with a bit of research in an industry you’re already familiar with? What do you do when you get push from other teams to rush things or get them out faster, when you know it’s not possible?

text: I usually use a “scale” approach, like “okay, i can get it done faster, but if I do i’ll be making assumptions that are unsupported by data and we may look bad if we’re called out on it. give me a few more days and we’ll have enough research to look more authoritative”

elements.text: I usually use a “scale” approach, like “okay, i can get it done faster, but if I do i’ll be making assumptions that are unsupported by data and we may look bad if we’re called out on it. give me a few more days and we’ll have enough research to look more authoritative”

text: if the overall timeline is the problem, you can say “okay i can focus on this project first, but that means putting our other projects on hold.”

elements.text: if the overall timeline is the problem, you can say “okay i can focus on this project first, but that means putting our other projects on hold.”

text: “Okay, I’m happy to prioritize this, but which of {list of projects} would you like to bump (and explain that this is why they were bumped)?”

elements.text: “Okay, I’m happy to prioritize this, but which of {list of projects} would you like to bump (and explain that this is why they were bumped)?”

text:
ALSO: if you’re asking as a freelancer, the correct answer is “sure, not a problem.” and work 38 hours to get it done

:+1:

elements.text: ALSO: if you’re asking as a freelancer, the correct answer is “sure, not a problem.” and work 38 hours to get it done

text:
As a freelancer that's subcontracted by agencies and other freelancers, I usually try and train my clients and my clients clients on a tacit SLA. For example, when we first start working together, I'll ask for 3 business days to do something that I can realistically crack out in an hour if you put a gun to my head (I don't scale this proportionally though—it's a 3 days standard whether the workload is 1 hour or 8. Things that could actually take me 8+ hours would shift into 6 business days, and so on.)

Once that becomes the norm, asks for things that need to be done "yesterday" tend to go away, or I can at least build in a big rush fee. This unapologetic buffer gives leeway for when things truly get swamped, and gives me room to maneuver if requests land on a Thursday afternoon and I had wanted a nice 3 day weekend for myself.

Almost NOTHING in marketing is truly an emergency. ("babies aren't dying" was a common mantra in my agency days when faced with silly ASAP requests.) 3 business days for net new asks should suit most asks. A 1,500 word blog post could range from 2 hours to 10 hours of actual work depending on a variety of factors, including the subjective nature of feelin' creative and vibin' with your craft. Expecting someone to produce such a thing in under 3 business' feels a little crazy.

This approach does of course depend on your clients/employer and how much insight they have into your productivity cycles, and the rhythm of demand upstream. If the culture is "crank out an article a day to appease the SEO gods" then this all falls apart. :stuck_out_tongue:

elements.text:

For example, when we first start working together, I'll ask for 3 business days to do something that I can realistically crack out in an hour if you put a gun to my head (I don't scale this proportionally though—it's a 3 days standard whether the workload is 1 hour or 8. Things that could actually take me 8+ hours would shift into 6 business days, and so on.)

Once that becomes the norm, asks for things that need to be done "yesterday" tend to go away, or I can at least build in a big rush fee. This unapologetic buffer gives leeway for when things truly get swamped, and gives me room to maneuver if requests land on a Thursday afternoon and I had wanted a nice 3 day weekend for myself.

Almost NOTHING in marketing is truly an emergency. ("babies aren't dying" was a common mantra in my agency days when faced with silly ASAP requests.) 3 business days for net new asks should suit most asks. A 1,500 word blog post could range from 2 hours to 10 hours of actual work depending on a variety of factors, including the subjective nature of feelin' creative and vibin' with your craft. Expecting someone to produce such a thing in under 3 business' feels a little crazy.

This approach does of course depend on your clients/employer and how much insight they have into your productivity cycles, and the rhythm of demand upstream. If the culture is "crank out an article a day to appease the SEO gods" then this all falls apart.

text: I'll give the short version: It usually takes me 8-10 hours to complete a 1500-words blog post with research and the whole shebang. But I say I'll deliver it in 3 days (+/- 2 days) since I have to account for other projects.

elements.text: I'll give the short version: It usually takes me 8-10 hours to complete a 1500-words blog post with research and the whole shebang. But I say I'll deliver it in 3 days (+/- 2 days) since I have to account for other projects.
